reviews.review_text: If Link and Samus had a baby and then taught it to play Dark Souls games then this would be that child

Wow. First hour in. Super impressed.  They've over-delivered. Pacing is spot on. Combat incredibly satisfying.  Several 'holy ♥♥♥♥, you can do that?' moments.  1 part muscle memory, 1 part twitch-reaction, 1 part enemy-priority juggling. Dash of ominous-yet-cheerful soundtrack. And ♥♥♥♥. It's gorgeous. 11/10, would have a sloppy makeout-session with the devs.   ****************************************************************** Couple things to consider before diving into this sexy-mess: ******************************************************************  1. I'm through and through a kb/mouse kind of feller. But you're probably going to want a controller for this one. Really feels right. This is the kind of game that's good enough that it's worth dropping the extra couple bucks if you don't have one on hand.  2. If you're looking for a casual wander-around and take in the sights sort of experience, you're going to be sorely disappointed. If you're bad at games, you probably won't finish this one. Not a lot of hand-holding going on here.

This is the best game I have played in a long time.  I hesitate to say the best Zelda-like game, because that would indicate that Zelda is better. And it's not. I don't say that casually - I love the Legend of Zelda series, but MAN, Nintendo got REKT here.  It is most like the original Legend of Zelda in that it is very free-roaming and is difficult, however, it teaches you the game in such a fantastically simple way. It requires no manual. You'll be able to get into it pretty quickly.  BREAKDOWN:  Gameplay: 10/10  The smoothness and variety of the combat and enemies is astonishing, far surpassing Zelda. You get energy for your gun by using your sword, making all of combat a mix of both. The dash and additional moves you learn make you feel like a master swordsman instead of a derpy Link. The elements teach themselves quite well.  Story: 7/10  This game uses absolutely no words, which is AWESOME. Dialog is done through pictures. It gives the whole game world a bit of an alien feeling, like you came to a foreign land. That said, I'm not sure I understood the overarching story very well. Extended cutscenes might help with that a lot.  Art: 10/10  The art in this game is absolutely astounding. I love it to death. Not annoyingly pixely, and very unrepetitive. It is beautiful. Just look at videos and pictures. SERIOUSLY.  Difficulty: 9/10  The difficulty in this game is almost perfect for me - it's difficult and the bosses will probably kill you several times, as will the levels leading up to them. The penalty of death, however, is merely starting the room over with the same stuff you had when you entered, which makes the difficulty really fun instead of annoying. Considering this light punishment, I would have liked some harder enemies to fight. I suppose though as someone who likes Dark Souls a lot, that means it will be perfect for a less masochistic player.  Overall: 9.5/10 - as awesome as Dark Souls, though in a different way  This is a must-buy. You won't regret it one bit. I wish there would be a sequel.

Hyper Light Drifter is one of my favourite games in years. I initially bought the game because I loved the visual design, but it ended up exceeding my expectations on every level. The visual style, the soundtrack, the storytelling, and the gameplay are all of the highest quality; they are complementary, and memorable.   When I initially played and finished the game, I was very satisfied and thought that I would probably play it again in a year or so. I ended up coming back in just a couple months, and found myself playing it through three times in a row, completing the majority of the game's optional challenges. I now know that this game will join a small handful of others that I return to and replay every year or so, which is probably the highest praise I can give.   If you want to play a beautiful game with an incredible artistic aesthetic, I strongly recommend this game. If you want to play a challenging but fair action game that is reminiscent of old classics, I strongly recommend this game. Support this game, we need more like it!

In an age where pixel indie games have become something of a cliché, Hyper Light Drifter brings some much needed life into the genre.  Hyper Light Drifter, or HLD for short, is an action-adventure game with its roots firmly placed in the Legend of Zelda games of yore. With a top-down perspective, a sword to slash around, an arsenal of weapons at your disposal, and a vast world to explore full of hidden secrets and goodies, it's nothing too alien. But yet, the world of HLD is entirely alien. While you might get a text crawl or dialogue in any number of Zelda games to explain what's goin on, HLD takes it in the complete opposite direction. There is absolutely no dialogue or text to speak of, save for a couple of lines in the tutorial and a note on how to use warps. Everything is represented through either pictographs, stories shared through images by NPCs, or directly by the environment itself. It is up to the player to understand what is going on on their own terms, much like the game Fez. But unlike the self-serving pretentiousness of Fez's presentation, HLD is a very gritty, brutal world that pulls no punches.  The graphical presentation is absolutely gorgeous. There is so much care and love put into the world to make it seem alive. There are tons of sprites and art pieces that are only used once, just for a small (or large) piece of scenery. The animations on the enemies, friendlies, and the player are top-notch and completely smooth. Each of the four zones are completely distinct with one another, united only by the center of the map. My humble opinion is that this is THE best pixel-style graphics you can see in any modern indie game today. It does so much with subtle color variations that it puts its peers to shame. While some might claim that certain games from the 16-bit era might fare better, that's not the point. When put in a group of its own stylistically similar peers, HLD is head and shoulders above the rest of the pack.  And what better way to suit the graphics than to have crisp, fun gameplay? HLD relies on three primary mechanics, each of them simple in their own right. Swing your sword. Fire a gun. Dash from place to place. But it's what you can do with your own personal abilities that can make it much more effective. You can upgrade to chain-dash endlessly, charge up your sword to whack enemies into the abyss, chuck bombs, fire anything from a shotgun to a railgun, the latter of which is helped by the fact that 'ammo' is generated by slashing your enemies. This promotes a quick and brutal style of combat, in which the enemies have certain patterns and behaviors that you can manipulate to your own advantage. Homing rockets heading your way? Easy, either slash through it or guide it into a baddie. Gunners shooting at you from afar? Reflect the bullets right back at them. On top of this, the amount of secrets, be it the mysterious monolith tablets to the 185 gearbits, to even outfits that help boost an aspect of your character, like faster bomb regeneration or an extra bit of health.  The soundtrack is wonderfully set to the mood of the locations you visit. Grungy, popping beats in the midst of battle to a quiet ambience in the gloomier areas, there's a lot of variation to find. What's more important is not only how consistent the quality of the music is, but how well they transition from room to room. Instead of having a fixed track for a specific room, they transition from the previous room flawlessly and often become incorporated into a single song. No matter where you go or what you do, you always feel like you're making progress in the world.  That doesn't mean the game is perfect, however. Finding those last few secrets can be a little bit of a chore and the underground map might as well not exist, because it barely makes any sense. Dashing from platform to platform, while a non-issue in most cases, it's rather hard to keep a straight path and you often find yourself veering off-center frequently. And not to mention, some rooms are almost unfairly brutal with their layouts.  In an age where the promises of a developer are more often than not hollow, short-sighted, and disappointing, HLD is a lovely total package that every game should aspire to be or at the very least, take some pointers from. It doesn't try to reinvent the wheel or present itself as something entirely new. It's a game that knows its boundaries, respects them, and instead perfects what's inside those boundaries than trying to be a little of everything at once.  Fantastic game, a must-play game for those who enjoy action-adventure games.  9/10.

It is, by far, one of the most challenging-but-fair games I have played. The controls feels just right and responsive, in almost all fights I have played there's a way to get all your opponents without taking a single hit from them, but that requires master timing and precision. As everyone said, the ambient, scenarios, music... all matches amaizingly well on this game. It is hard? Yes. Of course it will be hardest at first, but trial and error teach very well how the game mechanics works. Already one of my favorites on my library!  PS: The game has LOCAL Co-Op mode if you plug in a controller and hit start. It will take you one of your five health bars to spawn the second player, but it will have full health. The second player does not have medkits, and spawns without ammo. But, keep in mind! Bosses will have twice as much health!

A beautiful, neon, anime-inspired 'Link to the Past' with great combat & exploration. The art style was enough for me to buy the game and I was immediately blown away by its stunning opening sequence with its visual nods to Akira, Nausicaa, & End of Evangelion. The game is hauntingly scored by Disasterpeace with a mood similar to his IT FOLLOWS soundtrack, eerie and dreamy. Difficulty isn't an issue, there's some challenging boss fights but with forgiving checkpoints and an upgrade system, every battle can be triumphed with satisfaction. I only played through it once and didn't find all collectibles, but I highly recommend it and greatly enjoyed by time.
A challenging Zeldalike that focuses on quick movement and combat.

Simply put, this is one of the best games I've played in a while, brings back so many good memories from my favorite Legend of Zelda game: A Link to the Past and at the same time adding awesome combat mechanics with a spot on difficulty similar to Dark souls. It has everything an old school fan could ask for, I'm glad games like these are being made in this day and age. Nostalgia is hard on this one, 10/10 for me.

Pros: This game offers interesting challenges, great art and a wide range of secrets waiting to be discovered. Some sections of the game are merciless both in setting and gameplay and will probably require a lot of tries to get through. For character progression, the game rewards exploration rather than grind.  The Linux port seems to be working pretty well on a Radeon HD 7770 using the Catalyst driver. If you're gaming on Linux, this is most definitely worth it.  Cons: Any completionist will inevitably have to spend a lot of time trying to push through walls and peeking from cliffs. Some of the hidden secrets seem to be unreasonably difficult to deal with, in particular the dash challenges. Why would you ever do anything like that?

Actually one of the best games I have ever played. If you love the the 8bit and 16bit Zelda games with a challenge that could rival a souls game. A soundtrack that will make your ears orgasam. With art direction that has some of the best pixel art I have ever seen. Pick this one up for sure, Couldn't recommend it more. Why haven't you bought it already?

Don't be fooled by my short played time.... I bought this game on GoG as well.  Yes. Thats right. I bought it twice.  LegendOfMetroidSouls - Legend of zelda - meets metroid/vania - meets dark souls.... what else needs to be said?  Oh, thats right. Its absolutely GORGEOUS.  And the storytelling? No words... but its all there, beautifully rendered in imagery... artistic interpretation and a sense of imagination is needed to get the story.  But the game play is so awesome and 'simple' to pick up, that if you are the type to ignore the story, you can.  Don't think for one moment though that 'simple to pick up' means easy though...  Yes, the game is forgiving with save points pretty often, and you just restart at that save point when you die. Not if. When. You will die... often. Get used to it. (disclaimer - sure, someone out there somewhere will post a no-death playthrough eventually....)  Its gorgeous, it scratched the zelda itch I had been nursing for some time... and a few other itches I didn't even know I had.... buy this damn game already!

I hate to say this about a game I backed in the Kickstarter phase, but I'm just not really digging on Hyper Light Drifter. I mean, it's really pretty, and it had an interesting idea going with the no-words storytelling, but...it was just so obtuse, I had no idea what was or had been going on, and as a result, had no curiosity about what was going to happen, because it was bound to make equally little sense. Plus, the controls feel unnatural, and there's no way to customize them. All that combined with the challenge level of the game leads to me just getting frustrated at dying over and over again and not having any motivation to keep playing.

One of the most aesthetically pleasing games I've ever played.   Every single aspect of it, from the beautiful pixel art to the color palettes to the ambient music, contributes to the very immersive and enthralling atmosphere of the game. There's a simple joy in exploring this mysterious world, filled with anthropomorphic creatures that speak in pictures, long dead giants whose bodies have become part of the environment, and an intiguing mixture of fantasy and sci-fi elements.  The story is kept vague and relies mostly on contextual clues from the surroundings, but that doesn't stop the game from having a cohesive if slightly cryptic narrative. The game encourages exploration and discovery, with many many secret rooms and items to uncover, and there's a genuine sense of accomplishment from finding little hidden pieces of the overall puzzle.  As for the actual gameplay, it's challenging but fair. The combat relies a lot on good timing and reading your enemies, and you can unlock quite a few cool guns and upgrades. The dash move is especially useful, and makes the battles feel very fast paced and nerve-racking. And even though there are still some pretty difficult parts (made worse by the fact that checkpoints don't happen as often as I'd like) it never crosses the line into frustrating.  All in all, a very memorable and enjoyable game!
Like Zelda on crack, and you probably have to be on crack to beat this game.

Absolutely superb.   What a wonderful, beautiful game.  It looks incredible, it controls wonderfully. There's a lot of fast, hectic combat but it never feels like a chore to play. When you die, you feel like it's your fault and not the game's, and it spurs you to try harder and get better and style on that god damn boss. There's a rich, incredibly atmospheric land to explore, there's secrets and little bits of storytelling in every nook and cranny. There's a haunting, cryptic narrative to uncover.   It's been a while since a game clicked this well with me, everything just worked and to top it off the game doesn't overstay its welcome. Wonderful stuff, well worth the wait as a kickstarter pledger.

Only a few hours in, so I haven't had the time to go in depth with the gameplay and the story.   I have always been a fan of this type of art style and Hyperlight does it amazingly. The opening to the game is one of the most visually and musically stunning things I've ever seen from a game.  The gameplay is extemely fun and challenging. The game recommends using a controller, and it definately helps with the fast passed gameplay. The enemies are numerous and varied, and most of them require different strategies to defeat. The combat is very challenging, but it is tight and fluid, so once you learn it, it is very enjoyable.  Because there isn't any dialogue, it took me a little while to figure out what I had to do, but after some snooping around, it is pretty straightforward.

Hyper Light Drifter is a challenging game that has a beautiful art style. In terms of its story, it is subject to interpretation. Regardless of how you interpret the story, I genuinely enjoyed the game because of its controls, reactionary gameplay, and design. The only possible 'complaint' I could have is that it's a bit short (4 hours of gameplay, but that's not bad for a non-AAA title) and I guess also having multiple abilities didn't really seem to make a difference for me. I wish there were more abilities or actions you could do to change up battle strategies a bit, but this is just a minor thing in my opinion. I had fun and I think that most people would enjoy this game as well.  If I had to give it a rating (not a numerical score), I'd say it is above average and interesting.

Hyper Light Drifter combines Hack and Slash gameplay with a unique dashing ability and additional skills to create pretty fun fights - any boss fights are no exception to this.  The visuals and soundtrack fit incredibly well, and further set the tone of the game, to a point where you don't even need dialogue or the like to follow through. You'll understand the gameplay basically by yourself (and have to, since there is only a very basic tutorial), and the story unfolds itself over time.  Even if you may not be a fan of the core gameplay, another important part of the whole thing is exploration, since you have to do a lot of it to find everything there is in the game. It does get pretty tedious later on, but certainly isn't anything unfair. Most completely-out-of-sight secrets are just additional content, and not required to progress. This does require you to also be fine with backtracking, since it would be basically impossible to beat the game without returning to where you came from.  Definitely recommended, alone for the atmosphere from the first few minutes of the game.

Beautiful aesthetic, interesting gameplay, nicely done ambient music, frustrating problems. I know this seems to be an indie darling right now, but already I find myself constantly annoyed with the game.  The artwork looks nice in stills, but in practice leads me to be constantly unsure of what things are. Is that something I can stand on, or will I fall? Is that a wall, or something I can walk past? Is this something that will block projectiles?  I am also annoyed by the animations. The animation for healing makes you briefly stand still, during which time you still take damage. When you are knocked down, you are still capable of being damaged as you get up - or in some frustrating cases, knocked down again. When you dodge, there is a brief period where it looks like your character is ready to attack but cannot. Sometimes when dodging I can pass through projectiles without taking damage, but other times I cannot - I still do not know which is the intended result.  Less annoying but still questionable is the decision to give as little information to the player as possible. The first time I went into a store, I had no idea why I couldn't purchase something. I was similarly confused when I got my first piece of currency, when I pulled my first purple arrow thing out of the ground, and when I had a key and could not enter a locked door. I was also unsure about which direction I was meant to set out in, and apparantly picked the most difficult dungeon first.  The negatives out of the way, I want to talk about the positives. The setting of the game is mysterious and beautiful, the kind of place you want to learn more about. The music I thought was very fitting for this, and combined with the sound effects the game was quite a pleasure to hear. The enemies are varied and interesting, and this leads to combat that is surprisingly well done for such a lo-fi game. The developers have put some great work into the game - it originally was released at 30 fps max, but after player requests they went back and redid everything to make it run at 60.  Overall, I felt the flaws outweighed the positives. I know other people will be able to get past them to appreciate the game underneath, but I found myself constantly frustrated by the problems above.

Just finished the game recently. And I have to say that its pretty good! First of all the art style of the game is awesome. I liked most of the areas, especially those areas with machineries and stuff. I would recommend this game to people who misses old adventure and metroidvania kind of games. Games like Castlevania, Megaman, Metroid, etc are kinda absent in today's current gen. But I would guarantee you that Hyper Light Drifter would fill that void in some way. ; ) It is a hard game but a very satisfying experience. And its a good game to play while you're also waiting for Dark Souls 3. Ok now time for bullets!   PROS:  - The Art style is amazing! It definitely took inspiration from animes like Evangelion and action adventure games of old.  - Pixel Art and Animation. There isn't much games anymore with Pixel art. And good thing Hyper Light Drifter is to the rescue. - The Combat is good also. I kinda felt like I was playing Zero from Megaman Z, but with a isometric view instead.   And DASH DASH DASH. If you love Dashing in games you'll definitely love this.  - Combat difficulty. Now this game is a bit hard, and I think its trying to appeal to the audience of the Souls Series and similar games. So if you like hard games. Get this!  CONS: - The Game is SHORT! Now this is a mix bag. A lot of people love short games for easy consumption. And a lot of people love long games to have more playtime and enjoy their money's worth. I think I finished it in around 7-8 hours. I want more :(.  - The distribution of the health packs along the areas and dungeon was a bit bad. Having a place to store your health packs would've helped. (You might experience reaching the Boss with 1 or 0 health pack, then you would backtrack to get more).  - Music. This is a mix bag also. Some people would see this as a PRO rather than a CON; vice versa. But for me the music of the game wasnt good. While it does fit the futuristic techno machine aesthetic and atmosphere of the game, it didnt really capture me. It wasnt really memorable, except for the song during the ending. And Most of the boss battle music wasnt good. Bottom line this isnt the type of game soundtrack you would listen to after playing the game.  - Frustrating Platforming. There are certain areas where you need to be quite good at Chain Dashing. While I like the Dashing mechanic in this game, it can be hard and inconsistent at times.   Despite its shortcomings. I think its awesome art style and combat is awesome enough to give it a recommendation. There are people who are gonna have trouble with its length, so maybe you can wait for a steam sale before getting this. But I assure you despite it being a short game, it is really good! So why delay it if you can get it now. ;)

Hyper Light Drifter is one of my favorite gaming experiences on any platform, of any genre, from any era...  I love games that start with something simple, like great combat, and then build and polish a game around that core idea. The Developers at Heart Machine clearly started with combat mechanics as the focus of Hyper Light Drifter, and they did a stunning job of creating combat that feels altogether unique and familiar. It shares many similarities to the strategic hack n' slash found in games like Monster Hunter or Dark Souls. You have to be precise and calculated with every action to avoid being punished, but enemies have clear patterns and tells to learn.  Hyper Light Drifter is an Action Adventure game with light RPG elements. In the air of classics like Legend of Zelda, Metroid, or Castlevania you explore to find loot, upgrade your gear and abilities, and open up previously inaccessible areas. A classic formula that Heart Machine clearly understands.  This game leans more into combat as apposed to the more puzzle oriented dungeons of LoZ. Hyper Light Drifter is more like a top-down Symphony of the Night or Aria of Sorrow in that sense. The bosses and dungeon hordes are both varied and challenging. You die often, but the game is always fair and you want to jump right back in to get better at the game. That is something that should not be overlooked in any game. Checkpoints strike a balance where you are back in the action quickly, but you don't feel like the game is helping you along when you haven't earned it yet.   On top of all of the excellent gameplay is a gorgeous art direction and one of the best soundtracks of any game in existence. The visuals and the sound bring this world to life in a way that gave me chills at moments. Hyper Light Drifter doesn't try to convince you of it's lore or gameplay with dialogue boxes of text or combat tutorials, it shows you with emotional cutscenes and smart game design. It's cryptic and thought provoking. You aren't given absolutes that ring hollow, but instead bits and pieces of information to put together to form your own conclusions about the who, the what and the why.   If you haven't played this game yet please do yourself and favor and buy it now...  10/10

What I like about Hyper Light Drifter is more than just satisfying combat, an immersive atmosphere, the stylistic use of the art medium, masterfully crafted level design, and a feeling of discovery behind every secret passage way, nook, and cranny you come across (all of which it has oodles of). This game perfects a method in creating an experience, in telling a story, that goes beyond conventional narration and theme. It does this by both hiding and slowly revealing details at a pace that leaves you always grasping for more, but always satisfied by what you've discovered. While there are no words and the only communication with other characters is through sets of descriptive images of scenes, the player will understand the purpose and meaning of Hyper Light Drifter if they look carefully enough. You have one simple goal in Hyper Light Drifter, explore and uncover powerful artifacts of the past. Your motivation is as simple and deadly as any in the real world, a terminal and mysterious illness. As you explore more and more of the beautifully drawn and animated world of Hyper Light Drifter, you'll discover the dark secrets of the hidden past and why the Drifter is going down this path. The biggest strength of this game might actually be the ambiguity the story telling allows. Similar to games like Journey in this respect, you'll fall in love with Hyper Light Drifter becuase it lets you unravel the mystery of events in the game's universe rather than shouting a plot at you. This gives a special and personal significance to the character of the Drifter and the circumstances that befall him in the player's heart, not because they are told to like the character, but because they discover they do through their own experience controlling him. I DEFINITELY recommend this game, you will fall in love if you appreciate the deep care and effort an artist puts into their work. With the wonder of a Miyazaki film and the depth of a Souls game, Hyper Light Drifter is one of the best games to come out in the last year, and Heart Machine deserves much more credit than what they're already given for creating it. Thank you.

Imagine a Zelda game set in the future. Then pump that up to ELEVEN.  In Hyper Light Drifter you play a nameless wandering soldier with a sword on a quest of unknown purpose, plagued by an unknown illness and haunted by nightmares of death and destruction. You aren't given a clear picture of the goal, or even what you should do NEXT most of the time, but that's okay. Much like a classic Zelda game, you have freedom to explore and do as you please, and discover new secrets for yourself, and there are a TON.  The game is also much more action-packed. From the start you are equipped with a 'dash' function which can be spammed as often as desired (although there is a slight pause after using it 3 times in a row). The primary function of this dash is to let your character leap over short gaps between platforms, but it's also quite useful for dodging and weaving through the battlefield, approaching enemies for the kill and making a quick escape from a big attack. Players will be encouraged to use the dash as much as desired, and mastery will result in some of the flashiest, high-speed ninja fights ever seen in a Zelda-style game!  There are shops in town that sell you incredible but not-altogether-necessary upgrades, such as new moves you can do with your sword, more ammo for your guns (THERE ARE GUNS BY THE WAY), and a grenade to add to your movekit.  Heavy on story and gameplay with absolutely no dialogue (the game foregoes dialogue in favor of imagery), freedom of exploration reminiscent of oldschool Zelda games and some high-intensity action-packed combat for you hack-and-slash nuts, although calling it that is a dis-service as lack of care or thought given to when and how you move and strike will leave you dead. But, anyway, the game is amazing, okay?  Did I mention it's difficult? Punishingly so, at times, but in a good way that makes you feel like you're learning how to do something each time you 'die'.  If I have one piece of advice for you, it's start in the east. When you beat it, you get a shotgun!!!

Hyper Light Drifter is a 2D action game in the style of early Legend of Zelda games, specifically A Link to the Past for the SNES, as the game features a top down camera and involves exploring an overworld with several small dungeons tucked away. Furthermore, the launch was crippled by FPS drops, but it has since been patched out and the game ran without any issues for the duration of my first playthrough.  The Good: +Excellent combat that relies on timing and mastery of the players abilities. +Fluid pixel art that is easy on the eyes. +Fantastic music by Disasterpiece, the same artist that produced the music for Fez and Shoot Many Robots. +Lots of secrets, hidden paths and upgrades hidden around every corner of the map and dungeons. +The story and narrative is told without dialogue, much like Journey was, which makes for a different experience. +Enviromental puzzles and challenges break up the hack and slash action.  The Bad: -The game has superb boss fights, but could've used more, especially since the last zone featured more than one. -Some enemies will knock your character over and hit you again, before you can dodge away, leading to cheap deaths. -Due to opting out of dialogue the story does seem somewhat shallow. -Secrets fall between just being in a corner or having incredibly obtuse sollutions that aren't always explained.  Bottom Line:  Hyper Light Drifter is a love letter to old retro games and flaunts great gameplay, tells a simplistic story and at times, delivers crushing difficulty. For those looking for a retro challenge this is it, however those looking for less action and more pure exploration should look elsewhere.

I picked up Hyper LIght Drifter after being drawn in by the pretty visuals and promise of Dark Souls-like difficulty. I ended up getting a refund because the difficulty wasn't in the timing or attacks, or learning enemy attack patterns, it was instead reliant on clunky controls.  The Good: -Gorgeous and simplistic visuals -Immersive soundtrack that draws on the surreal cyberpunk/fantasy aesthetics -Combat feels good and satisfying when the game engine allows for it -Moderate array of weaponry allows for healthy variety in gameplay -Non-linear progression promotes exploration  The Bad: -Controls are not 100% responsive -Can't dash through enemies, but they can pass through you with attacks and you can dash over gaps. Sends mixed signals to the player. -Mechanics could use SLIGHTLY (and I mean miniscule) more explanation. This also ties into exploration which is encouraged because of upgrades but secrets were too tedious to look for. -Ranged weapon aiming is just straight garbage using controller or mouse. Where I aimed would consistently not be where my character would actually shoot.  Overall this would have been a 100% recommended game but I have little patience for games that promote crushing difficulty but hide it behind poor technical limitations. This game was shooting to be a 2D Dark Souls game with much better art direction and soundtrack but the loose combat and unresponsive controls made me feel like I was fighting the game engine instead of the enemies on my screen.

Alright. Played two hours of actual game so far with the other seven being the Preview Build. Part 2 - 17.5 hours full release completion  Basically all the stuff I said in the first review along with some extras. All the bosses were interesting and having some level of strategy to them with the things that made each of them unique from one another. The use of upgrades for both your weapons and your dash ability is super satisfying, killing the final boss with six of his projectiles reflected back at him was awesome. I personally enjoyed the story being told only through images, cinematics, and the areas instead of text like most other games. Each area was unique in design and asthetic and had some sort of backstory you could learn from the npc you can talk to in each area. As you play the game you are likely to grow attached to the other drifter you meet in each area   and feel terrible and it is your duty to avenge him when he eventually dies  . The six different guns in the game are, well, different from one another and call all be used to take on a situation differently whether you want to snipe at a distance, shotgun up close, or use a pistol as a utility between sword attacks. Half of the people in the forums are great people and have come together to find many interesting secrets, help one another, and even translate the igname language. The other half cant stop complaining about 30fps which doesnt bother everyone in the world and some people mentioned in the Special Thanks part of the credits (btw, the ST part of the credits is nearly always pooled from all the devs in any production, meaning that the ideals and thanks of one can completely conflict with the ideals and thanks of the others. Overall, this game was a great 17.5 hour adventure rpg (nearly 100%) with great combat, visuals, soundtrack, and an interesting story with a bitter-sweet ending. I recommend it to anyone in need of a fun game that requires you to think and recommends searching every nook and cranny.

(There's few spoilers here and there) At the time of writing this review I finished main story with ~25 modules and ~10 keys.  TL;DR The game's good, but it's not nearly as good as I hoped it would be. I recommend you play the preview build which is much better than the final product in my opinion.  Full review (In no particular order): + Atmosphere is really good; excellent ambience music, detailed surroundings and animations. + Game looks gorgeous, and it's aware if it showing you few vistas from time to time. + I found the story intriguing from the very beginning, partly thanks to that creepy intro. It's minimalistic, mysterious. Its lore is interesting to dig up. + Fighting's done very well; it's fast-paced and you can always be in control.  + Level design of most areas is impressive, most secrets have some hint. + Overall boss fights are challenging and interesting. + Enemies are somewhat varied...  - ...although each has max 2 attacks and most have only one. - There are only few interesting characters/stories in the world. And they are short and simple. - In some fights game throws at you large numbers of same type of enemies - it's challenging, but it's not interesting (conversly some fights have waves set up really well). - 'open-world' doesn't work for me in this game. The world feels too small and cramped. I feel like it would work better in Demon's Souls style world with warpins only from/to selected places and no direct connections between the hub and the zones. - weapon upgrading is just redundant in its currect form. - some secrets require wall-hugging/sixth sense to be found. - map is useful only for collecting modules - Big problem is the amount of content that's not present in final product, although you can see it in 2014 trailer and Kickstarter goals. Bosses, weapons, areas, modes. Even without knowing about it you can fell the game is rushed, especially in South-surface area.  Overall the game's functional (for me), and it's fun that's why I still recommend it, but at the same time I know that HM can do much better. I think that just the scope of what they wanted to make was too much for them, that's why the cuts.  So why I recommend preview build? It's essentialy the best designed section of the final game, but designed even better. It feels much more complete and coherent. Every secret has some hint, no wall-hugging's needed. It has nearly all that final game nails, and omits elements that didn't work out as much. You only have to accept the fact that it's just a preview build, so it's 2h long.  PS I might edit this review later if anything will spring to mind.

(10 hours of my game time is in BETA build)  Finally finished Hyper Light Drifter... I will regard it as one of my dream games.  I can go on about the breathtaking pixel artstyle and excellent sound design... but I will choose not to as you already can get the hint from the trailers and other users.  What I will be describing here is my personal unbiased experience of the gameplay.    PROS:     1) Fluid and Responsive combat:  that requires the right timing in order to overcome your enemies. Every enemy has a window of oppurtunity to strike them hard including the super challenging bosses. Resulting in a deadly dance of death as you drift around the battle field slashing your enemies before they can strke you and drifting away at just the right moment. Rarely have I played a combat so satisfying, easy to learn and hard to master.   2) Bosses:  seldom have I faced challenge in recent past when a game threw me a boss. Reminded me of the good old days when overcoming a boss felt like a real achievement to show off. Every boss fight is unique and memorable!  Those negative reviews that you have been reading about super hard bosses is only a complaint of people who didn't try enough. Personally it took me around 10 tries for each boss to beat (including the last one). I am not a super pro at games and consider myself average.   The key is knowing your enemy and timing your attacks and using your upgraded abilities by thinking on your feet. It is NOT unfair. Bosses are supposed to be super hard. Deal with it.   3) Exploration:  The world of HLD is brimming with secrets galore... every nook and cranny can lead to a secret pathway containing rare gold artifact that you can use to buy upgrades for your arsenal.   4) Enemy Variety:  Every region has seprate enemy units, behaviour and asthetics. Never did the game become boring slash and hack button smasher as every new enemy makes you think on your feet to deal with.     CONS:     1) Short:  yes you might argue good things come in small packages but yes I believe they could have expanded each region further and add more sidequests than the overarching quest you already have. More dugeons would have helped feel the RPG and exploration aspect too. However they chose to focus and make this game purely action oriented. A lost oppurtunity if you ask me.  The intense actions sequences could have been more paced out with longer gameplay and the loot collection meta game could have breathed more space with more environments and dungeons.   2) Upgrades:  Though each sword and dash upgrade is unique and useful in their own way, I felt guns could have been added with more interesting modules and addons such that modifies the shot pattern or bullets. They could have hidden these modules in secret places to make things more interesting... instead of plain upgrades to magazine.   Bastion is a fine example of how to enhance gameplay by adding tactical addons to your existing arsenal. I felt HLD creators lost a lot of oppurtunity here in that regard.   3) Lack of Adventure:  You already have all the map revealed to you in the very beginning of the game. I felt it kind of personally took away the wonder and adventure of the game which is based on exploration. Yes the map is abstract, yes you dont know the terrain or the enemy positions of the regions before you visit them, and yet I felt kind of put off by it.   4) No proper quest system:  Except your main quest you never encounter any NPCs giving you sidequests of clearing dungeouns / discovering hidden artifacts in lost temples. This serously kind of bummed me as I expected it to be an Action-Adventure-RPG instead they focused it on Action-RPG.  This could have elivated the game to an altogether different level. Side quests could have been equally cryptic in nature I wouldn't have mind that.  The game therefore feels a LONG fetch quest for your main questline.     RECOMMENDED   If you like intense action RPG with a challenging gameplay and breathtaking art and sound production. HLD is one of those rare indie gems that comes out once a blue moon.  It has its shortcomings only because they could have made this into a even bigger and better masterpiece of a game than what it already is.  Rating (if that matters): 8.5/10

I had a long review written up, but then I accidentally switched windows and lost all that I wrote (R.I.P. me), so I'll keep this succinct:  - Story is told visually only, no dialogue. It's vague, a lot of it left up to interpretation, but told very well regardless. Expect a lot of debate over the game's lore and its meaning.  - Presentation is amazing, if you like retro stuff. Art is pixel art, all hand-made from scratch, and music is beautiful, most of it in the form of ambiance. Visuals and audio put together, it's a spectacle to witness. I advise lowering game volume, though, certain cutscenes in the game spike the volume extremely high.  - Game is hard. Very hard, in regards to both lesser enemies and bosses alike. Especially bosses. Not sadistically difficult, though, difficult in a forgiving, 'You messed up but can try again' kind of way. Doesn't hold your hand at all, but gives you many options to keep going. Death checkpoints are decent; some very forgiving, others not so much.  - Combat is very satisfying. Sword strikes and gun shots alike have a big impact to them. Very reflex-based, 'stay aware and keep on the move' kind of combat.  - Exploration is abundant. Good amount of ground to cover and tons of secrets to find and scavenge for.  - Progression is RPG-like; have to find gold pieces that combine into full gold to buy skills/equipment from town hub shops. Encourages exploration to further upgrades.  - Kind of short game if you take away difficulty. I beat it in around 7 hours, which is not bad, but depending on who you are, it may leave you wanting for more. Rarely a game comes along that gets me excited enough to buy it the minute it comes out. Hyper Light drifter is one of those rare games, and it doesn't dissapoint.  At the time of this review I'm only two hours in, but I'm already hooked. Hyper Light Drifter is a hack and slash that hits every note with perfect precision, and manages to add it's own beautiful twist that makes it unique. Let me explain.  The Atmosphere: You are probably already aware that the art style is absolutly fantastic, but the trailers don't give away the full story. Each set piece feels like it is well thought out, and each screen is beautifully composed. Even more so, the music adds to the atmosphere and mood without being distracting or obtrusive. The sound of this game strikes a fantastic balance between emotive expression and being a delicate background foundation to the game. Even the sound effects feel masterfully created. I can not rave about the way this game presents itself more. It is top shelf.  The Story: So far I'm only right at the very start of the game, but the story has already drawn me in, and it has managed to do so with absoltly no text. This game takes the idea of 'show, don't tell' very seriously, and it absolutly delivers. It didn't take very long at all for me to become invested in the characters, and the world feels very real and lived-in. It is hard for me to find fault. Granted, this early on it is entirely possible for the story to fall appart later on, but given how expertly the beginning of the game is constructed, I highly doubt the rest of the story will be anything but fantastic. I'm excited to discover more about this world and the people who inhabit it.  The Combat: No game is perfect, and Hyper Light Drifter is no exception. The combat feels tight and responsive, but beyond that it doesn't really introduce anything too exciting. Combat is neither brutally hard nor boringly easy, but it can be a little frustrating. Enemy's attacks will follow you accross the screen after you dash out of the way, which can lead to the annoying experience of dodging an enemy's attack only to have the enemy fly accross the screen and kill you anyway. Combat is a little punishing, with enemy's two-hitting you from very early on, meaning you have to play perfectly to progress, and might need to retry a fight ten or more times before you can move on. The ranged weapon feels pretty underpowered, with very limited ammo and an awkward aiming system. Using the gun often feels like a waste of time and effort. Your sword is much more effective, and doesn't cost ammo. On top of that your abilities are the same powers we've seen a hundred times over. One melee attack, One ranged attack, and a dash. Don't get me wrong, the combat is /fine/, but it is only fine where the rest of the game is great.   All up this game does not dissapoint, and I'm excited to see where the game takes me and what the company produce in the future. Solid performance.  TLDR; Game is good. Spend $$$.

This is definitely one of my favorite games of 2016.  Upon first glance, the game has a minimalistic yet beautiful pixelated art style that's well complimented by it's high contrast, neon-esque color scheme that helps bring a weird, alien atmosphere to the game world. The soundtrack, also atmospheric, is heavy on synths and filters that could very well be a moody take of John Carpenter's pieces. These two aspects together helps bring this torn and twisted world to life.  The game starts with a short cutscene with your character, The Drifter, as he watches his world crumble around him, and collapses during a struggle against a tentacled being. The Drifter is rescued by a mysterious man in plated armor and taken to a house in a village. The Drifter wakes up, and then he's on his own.  The game is definitely inspired by the likes of The Legend of Zelda and Dark Souls, seeming to be a mix between the two, but the action is much faster than the two. You're given a sword, a gun, and the ability to swiftly dodge as you're pitted against a variety of enemies across four different areas in the game. These areas are not only non linear and expansive, but they're also full of secrets filled with upgrades, called gear bits, and triggers that helps you open up more secrets. The gearbits, however, helps you upgrade your different abilities and give you extra ones as well. There's many ways you can upgrade your abilities, but the upgrades aren't tiered save a couple of upgrades, but every single upgrade is very useful.  One of the main attractions to the game are its boss fights. This is where I say the game may disappoint to some people. Some of the boss fights are lackluster in the boss's attack variety and some of them are pitifully weak, being able to be destroyed within your first encounter if you're a capable enough gamer. Only later through the game will your skills be truly put to the test as you're given tougher bosses to fight, although they're still considerably weak if you're using the right equipment. At least, this is how my first playthrough of the game felt on the standard difficulty. Compared to Dark Souls and even The Legend of Zelda, the bosses are subjectively easier than the waves of mobs you fight on the way to them. Despite this, most of the boss fights are still fun as each boss has abilities vastly differing from other bosses.  The game has some extra content, like challenge stages and mini games to play when you're not adventuring, but nothing too extraordinary compared to other games unless you count the secret doors you can access through the keys scattered around the game world. On a standard playthrough collecting some items, I'd say the game is around 8 hours long. However, I may very well give this game a second playthrough after I clear out some of my back log. I'd say this game is a solid 7/10 with a 5 being an average score. This game definitely stands out with its faster paced Zelda/Souls styled combat, but the game's climaxes to each area and even to the game itself fail to hold up to the rest of the game. It's a must-buy when its on sale, but if you have the money to spare, it's not a bad purchase either. At 20 dollars, this game has what I expect content wise, but the content in there is well crafted.

With top down gameplay inspired by zelda with a dash of unforgiving fast paced combat, HLD was worth the price of admission. The music atmosphere and animations make enemies and the main character a pleasure to watch as they attempt to dismantle eachother. The game is also dense with secrets, with unfortunately some boiling down to running against walls and leaps of faith.  I would wadger that a casual play through might clock in at 7-8 hours, depending on how many upgrades your willing to search high and low to finance. Almost all important additions to your abilities are bought from trainers, with the exception of guns that mostly lie behind the games major boss fights. Some are more useful then others: the chain dash is extremely important but upgrading your pistol clip or learning the slash into dash can wait.  There are issues: frame rate can make executing some of your moves difficult. Your character will sometimes drop dashes when chaining them and there's not much to do, and it gets annoying trying to execute a 7+ chain dash required to clear some of the more difficult puzzels and your imput dropping or your character skidding to his certain death. The secrets in some areas are well marked, but those same markers in the same broad area might just be junk on the floor. It is compounded partially by the style of graphics: the charming pixels with tons of doo-dads on the walls and floor mean that it looks like everything might have a switch or passage behind it.  You can't track where you've found things aside from the games diamond shards (which act as keys for progression) so you might wander an area for hours trying to find elusive secret collectables only to learn apon consulting a map that you've already cleaned it out long ago. Most of the rewards as you move to full collections tend to be minor: there are outfits that have different effects on them of varying use (some are quite subtle) but the most powerful effects they have are generally obtained past when they mattered anyway.   That being said there's a lot of fun to be had exploring and buying upgrades and fighting some very intense ambushes and bosses in the grim but very colorful ruins of hyper light drifter.

I'm not saying I didn't enjoy this game at all, but there's some issues with the gameplay that cripple what could have otherwise been a modern masterpiece. I'm going to outline a few of those problems here so you can decide if you want to purchase the game or wait for a sequel.  One, the pace of combat is frantic and clunky. Your dash doubles as your dodge maneuver but it pretty much always puts you so far away you can't retaliate. When it doesn't, you still get hit so then dodging was useless. Enemies that keep up with you make it where you have to completely dodge out of the way of all of them to try to recover and get some hits in. Doing more than 3 dashes in a row causes you to spin out and do nothing or bonk against a wall, then get hit by the enemies you were trying to avoid. Your attacks only cause a few enemies to recoil and you have to learn by trial and error which ones those are. Not to mention, enemies are attacking pretty much constantly but you have to tap your dashes in such a way that the rhythm causes your first two dashes to be slow, which can make dashing multiple times inherently useless in certain situations anyways. There's almost never a good break to use your very slow heal unless you back completely away from everything. Midway through the game there are just too many enemies, and the developers knew this: That's why they made it where when you die, you respawn at an unseen checkpoint, usually the same room you just died in, with all the ammo and healing slots you had on you when you triggered it. If they knew the game was this hard, they should have reworked some of the movement or the enemies, or something to make the game generally less of a non-stop trial.  Two, bosses are unimaginative. This is kind of mind-boggling, considering how amazing the aesthetics of this game are and the premise, the environments, all of that. This game is beautiful but the boss fights are not designed to be interesting. One of the easiest bosses you can get to, and will probably find first, summons additional monsters. This is pretty much a boss design crime. The boss itself has incredibly good tracking and attacks constantly, so you never have time to breathe or punish him except for a split second right at the beginning of his attack cycle, or while he's still attacking you at range. The pace is just way too hectic and doesn't let you learn anything except that you need to brute force the fight by dodging and attacking with no breaks or pauses. It's almost like playing a side-scrolling beat-'em-up instead of an adventure game.  Three, there's a huge missed opportunity with the music. Yes, the soundtrack and the environmental themes are *astounding* and pick up at just the right times to capture your imagination. But at the same time, you walk into a fast-paced beat-'em-up style boss fight like this and you get the same music (or same kind of music) you got exploring only swelling a bit. It stops sounding eerie and mysterious and just sounds drab and lazy for a boss. This game has some really epic story telling moments outside of boss fights. It could have had just as good moments where the music would switch to something frantic and berserk that fits the pace of the boss battle. It could have also had a little more ceremony surrounding this like other cut scenes do.  Four, the vast majority of the upgrades in this game are straight up garbage. I can think of 5 of them I would change or remove completely. I spent my hard earned hyperbucks on some new dashing abilities only to find out they are hard to trigger and don't really do much of anything. One of them was that chain dash that I described earlier as being pretty much useless except for a very limited number of circumstances. It can take you upwards of 30 minutes to an hour to get enough money to buy an upgrade but getting that upgrade very often does little to nothing for you. There's two defensive upgrades that are obviously superior to everything else, and after that all you really need is to buy more charge slots for your healing tool. Moreover, you can get costume items but they have a very minimal effect on your character, none of which is explained, the cosmetic differences of which are pretty limited. This means customization of your character is virtually nonexistent. In a game this aesthetically pleasing and interesting, this is a little disappointing.   Overall I'd give Hyper Light Drifter a 6 out of 10. There is some *amazing* artwork and incredible ideas here, they're just not accompanied by rewarding gameplay.

Go experience that sexyness again ;3  TLDR: Hyper Light Drifter was a wonderful experience, that felt and looked fantastic. Absolute recomendation to pickup full price or at a sale.  Hyper Light Drifter is a Top down, explorative Action RPG developed by Heart Machine through Kickstarter support a few years back.  The art, visuals, and controls feel impecable. Slashes have a nice swing to them, the dashes look excellent, the environment it beautiful on first glance, and the ambience music provides a wonderful vibe to the game. The controls feel like your standard twin stick shooter, but only rebindable for Keyboard+Mouse. Options may not be the best for some, and yes, it is locked at 30fps. I had no complaints, other than some sections where lots of flashing lights were present.  The game throws you in, arms open while you figure out which of the cardinal sections to go and collect some fragments. All of the game's cues are red herrings, as you can basically go any area you want (Except South). Most of the story is told through pictures, and sfx the Npc's make.   There is a very sudden learning curve, some may not enjoy it. Many have compared HLD to Titan Souls, or the other Souls variety, and you can feel that difficulty. You'll begin dashing around, slashing with guns blazing, but soon develop strategies against tougher bosses or opponents. The town sells skills/upgrades to your base dash, guns, sword, etc through credits you'll find over the world through fights and secrets. They only provide a singluar base upgrade, and most times feel fundamental in several fights, so come back from time to time and buy them.   Hyper Light Drifter has ALOT of secrets and thus backtracking/exploration of the levels. Most times, you'll have to take a dash of faith to see what lies off a cliff side, and can feel plain silly at times. The little widget, however, does provide ? cues when near the area, so slow down and mash the char against walls.   The game took me about 7 hours to complete, and does have a New Game+ mode making the game harder. You'll find yourself backtracking, exploring, and enjoying the minigames around town and the world area. Frustrations will happen. But if you take it methodically, and analyze your actions/enemy moves, the game becomes all the much more fun.  Hyper Light Drifter was a wonderful experience, that you truly can't experience again if you've watched other play it. So I recomend you snag it for yourself. It may be difficult at first, but you soon grasp what is happening, and come to ease with the difficulty. The game is well polished enough that you shouldn't run into many issues, and the experience should entertain you as it did me :3

Probably one of the indie games that people have been the hypest for, for the longest. Every single trailer we saw for HLD was atmospheric as hell. It looked gorgeous, it sounded gorgeous, it seemed to play gorgeous.  It's a shame they should've probably called it Overhyped Light Drifter instead.  It's not a fundamentally bad formula, but it's poorly executed. The almost-complete absence of words is great... if the game is entirely intuitive, which it isn't. The basic combat is a fine idea... if the controls aren't crap(seriously, the pistol mechanics? Why? Just why. Spiral Knights did basically the same controls, better, with mouse-and-keyboard, years ago. And that's a free-to-play game, the bottom of the barrel.). An absence of invincibility frames means that combat usually means one hit leads to a stunlock and you getting piled down to zero health. Enemies usually aren't challenging, they're just tedious, requiring you to do the same thing over and over again to kill them. And a dozen other small issues, wnone of which kill the game by themselves, but all of which, together, make it pretty unfun.  I could have forgiven most of this and done my best to enjoy the game, though, if not for the checkpoints.  Who ever thought it was a good idea to not put checkpoints in between instadeath traps? Or in between a tedious fight and an instadeath trap? I don't mind having to take a few tries and a bit of brainpower to get through a trap that can squish me in one go, but if you want to take that tack, please, don't make me have to redo OTHER parts every time I get squished, too.  And if you're going to require me to backtrack to doors that open up as I progress in other areas of the game... for God's sake don't have respawning enemies.  I really can't recommend that anyone buy this at all, barring some patch that really and truly overhauls the game.  It does really look and sound as nice as it did in the trailer, though, so I'd suggest waiting for some very patient LP'er to give it a spin, if you really have to see what they ended up making.

This game has some of the most intense, challenging, and rewarding gameplay I have ever experienced, while having extremely simple controls and mechanics.   Every environment is gushing with atmosphere, every fight is visceral and intense, every death just makes me want more. I am completely enamored.  When I started, I expected a non-stop action game, but the game is actually split between atmospheric exploration and combat and both are amazing.    Exploration:  This is one of the most immersive 2D games I've seen. Every bit of the map is beautiful, well-crafted and unique - even the most obscure secrets have a lot of cool details. Thorough exploration pays off significantly as there are an insane amount of secrets to find. (for those who would prefer skipping a lot of backtracking and secret-searching, it's not required to find many secrets to beat the game)   Combat:  Combat is quick, satisfying, and challenging. It often requires good reflexes and careful planning. I died often, but I rarely felt it wasn't my fault. Enemies and bosses have rigid patterns and attacks that can be quickly learned and exploited. Bosses are especially difficult and multiple attempts are expected, but it never felt hopelessly hard. It helps that the boss fights are cool as hell.   Story:  The story may be a weak point for some. Everything, including UI elements and speech, is told in pictures and scenery. The story is very loosely given and it leaves a lot of room for interpretation. On the other hand, the lack of text makes the environment far more effective at invoking a sense of awe and wonder.   Music/Sound:  The music is excellent and perfect for the game's setting. It's subtle but very situational and it changes dynamically as you progress through areas to match the tone.    Length:  The game will last anywhere from 3-4 hours (if you rush through) to 15+ hours for those who want to find everything. This is not including the additional New Game + mode and achievement-hunting (a no-death run sounds soul-crushing)   After beating this game twice, I wish I could experience it fresh again.

It's not that rare to find an indie game inspired by Zelda, Metroid, Secret of Mana, etc. - that's getting to be pretty well-worn ground these days. What *is* surprising is to find a game that lives up to those inspirations while also carving out its own areas of unique excellence. Hyper Light Drifter distingushes itself through its stunning visual design, meaty action gameplay, moody soundtrack, and hauntingly minimalist world building. I have some critiques but they are mostly just nitpicks...on the whole, this is an absolute *must-play* for any fan of challenging action games.  + The combat feels incredibly satisfying, your sword attack combo hits with a heavy 'thwak' that just feels great. It feels awesome to pull off a combo on an enemy, dash away to avoid their attack, and then dash back in for the finishing blow.  + Oozing atmosphere, the whole game is a masterclass in savvy and thoughtful art direction. Almost every section of the world is filled with the rusty husks of old robots, the dead and decaying remains of giant monsters, the ruins of an old but super-advanced society, etc. The little bits we get of the world and its history are incredibly compelling and very cleverly done...I definitely wanted *more* but I know that would be defeating the point.  + Disasterpeace was an ideal fit for the soundtrack - you really feel like a lonely wanderer in an alien world, kind of a Vangelis/Blade Runner kind of vibe. And when that boss theme kicks in, you know that serious business is about to go down.  + Challenging but fair. When you die, it's your fault. It's mostly just practice and getting used to enemy patterns. By the end of the game, I was able to beat the final bosses in a fraction of the time that it took me to beat some of the first bosses. This was less because I got strong upgrades (the upgrades mostly don't matter that much, I felt) and more from just spending time with the game.  + To me, a game like this lives or dies on its boss fights, and I wasn't disappointed here. The bosses are very memorable and tough and well-designed, I especially enjoyed the boss of the western crystal lands and the final bosses. You'll need to use all of your techniques, skills, reflexes, everything the game has taught you, and every trick you learned to exploit an enemy's weakness.  + A lot of replayability. I've beaten the game, but I didn't find all the keys, get all the secret nodes, beat that dang soccer kid (you'll see, he might be the hardest boss in the game), etc. After you've beaten the game, your last save will start off just before the final boss, so you'll still be able to go back and explore the world. There's also a New Game + option that is essentially just hard mode (you get less health but you start with all the upgrades) as far as I can see, but that doesn't interest me too much.  = The dash mechanic doesn't feel that great to use when you need to chain together repeated dashes, I could never really get the hang of doing more than a few dashes at once. I know others don't have this problem, your mileage may vary.  - Not a lot of enemy variety...each zone has its own unique monsters, but there are also a lot of repeats. Not the biggest deal in the world, but you'll find yourself fighting the same mobs over and over.  - Exploration isn't always super-compelling. You discover these awesome secret tunnels and special passages and then they just lead to...a health pack or a money bit. There aren't really any paths that lead to super-secret dungeons or crazy weapons or ultimate bosses or anything like that. There are some optional bosses in a certain area, but the game map tells you where to go. I would have liked a little more payoff for going off the beaten track.  - The game map is really vague and just a little bit too cryptic, it gives you a general idea of where you are but isn't always that helpful.

What to say. Words that compliment such a great game escape me. So lets go through this one step at a time. Strap yourself in this is gonna be a long one.  -Visuals- It is an amazingly beautiful game. Colorful yet somber at the same time. Each area has its own style and the enemies you face are part of that style. I don't have much to say, it's just such a beautiful game I found myself taking screenshots every so often to capture some amazing new sight.  -Story- I finished the game just as confused about the story as when I started, and I love that. I love games with a confusing story, one that reveals itself one step at a time and through the players actions and not just on its own. I guess this is why some people compare it to Dark Souls. Indeed the way their stories are set up and displayed is very similar. Throughout the whole game I found myself wandering through this war torn land just wondering what had happened.  -Gameplay/Combat- Lets start by talking about the in-town stuff here. The upgrade system here is very unique. You go along on your adventure and collect gears, four gears equals one point. The usual cost for upgrades is three points, which is pretty reasonable seeing as I almost had every upgrade by the end of the game. And I must say, it is quite a rewarding feeling beeting a boss, getting some gears, and going back to town to upgrade. It's a nice feeling of progression that I love.  Now for the combat. I absolutely love it. It's inventive and fast pased and just so fun. I love going into a room and getting ambushed. I'll dash to the first guy take him out in a couple slices, snipe the farthest guy with my laser rifle, throw a bomb and take out five more, and finally dash slice through the last bad guy. I found myself approaching the same areas in different ways and adjusting my level of aggression based on what enemies I fought. If a ranged enemy shoots a missile at me from afar I'll slice it in two and quick dash towards him for a heavy slice. Honestly I could go on with this forever. So moving on then.  -Bosses- Bosses get their own catagory because I feel in a game like this they are very important. Each boss has its own move set one that as you die and retry, you learn and adjust to. They are hard, very hard, that is if you go into it head on. Each boss makes you take a step back and think about each action you make, if you have time to heal, or how you might dodge this attack. I had the most trouble with the northern boss (spoilers), his ground AOE attacks were hard to get used to and you spend most of your time franticly dodging. I might have died twenty times to that guy. But you know what, I had so much fun. And most of all, it feels amazingly rewarding when you take a boss out, you may feel a weight lifted from your shoulders, knowing you bested one of the hardest enemies of the game.  -Conclusion- Its a great game. If you like Dark Souls, adventure, wonder, great art. and great music get this game...please. I haven't had so much fun in a mere ten and a half hours in a long time.

I loved this game so much! It is such an innovative experience, I wish more games were like this!  What I loved:  - 'Hands-off' Game Progression: The game espouses a welcome change from mainstream gaming and does not tell you how to progress, or force you into a single path of gameplay, much like its inspiration, The Legend of Zelda. There is a notable exception to this general rule, but this was done (I assume) for gameplay and story reasons.  - Exploration is Key: The game has done away with archaic concepts such as 'Lives' and 'Game Overs' or 'Continues'. Instead, the player is merely halted or impeded from progressing until the player solves the puzzle, or has acquired the necessary item to continue.  - Focus on Visual Style: The game relies very heavily on visual cues and detail to convey critical concepts and plot to the player, with sounds playing a secondary (but no less vital role).  - Excellent Controls: The controls and combat style is fresh and fluid, and has a unique dynamic that is only improved as the player upgrades his abilities on their adventure. The techniques available to the player have an endearing 'Easy to Learn, Hard to Master' quality to them, and radically alter the nature of combat in relation to the level of skill the player has, and his experience in dealing with enemy types. No matter how far the player has progressed, however, every enemy encounter has to be treated with a special form of respect or the player may find themselves surprisingly overwhelmed. I found this to add a welcome idea that even the super-skilled bad*** the player may become can still be done in by a rookie mistake.  - Superb Sound: For the most part the soundtrack is wonderful, the music and compostion are top-notch, and they lend themselves well to the various places and atmospheres the player will encounter in their travels. A side note: the sounds can grate on the senses after a while, especially if the player does not adjust the levels in the options menu to suit their preferences.  - Rich Level Design: What more can I say? Secrets abound in this game, and it stirs rewarding feelings in intrepid players who love nothing more than sweeping every nook and cranny of the map for treasure and hidden things! The top-down perspective really allows for some interesting ways to hide things and places from everyone but the most observant seeker.   What I Didn't Like:  - Rudimentary Map: The game in one instance borrows a bit too heavily from Legend of Zelda, in that the map is extremely limited in terms of function. This is mostly done to challenge the player to recognize their surroundings and where they are in relation to landmarks, but is it too much to ask to have a waypoint system? Or some kind of markers that can be placed on the map to make it easier to go back to secret areas or locked doors that you have found? I found myself (with my dubious art skills) trying to hand-draw maps on paper to remember where I found certain secrets. Immersion is one thing, but surely it wouldn't be very hard to code something like that into the game?  - Inscrutable Depth: Given that the greater part of the story is presented visually, it came as both a surprise and a bit of a gyp that there is text in the game, but that it is encoded in some kind of moon-man runic script, but the game itself does not offer you a cipher to decode it and find out what it means. I have heard rumors that some fans have actually run the script through translation programs and algorithms and gotten legible and understandable english text as a result, and that these shed more light onto the world of Hyper Light Drifter. I will admit that this is cool, but what about those players who do not have specialized cryptographic knowledge? Like me. I really love the game and the amount of love that the developers put into it, but the story of a game shouldn't play out like the Watergate investigation; I should be able to, without a guide or undue outside help, work on my own to discover the mysteries of the game. How hard is it to include a book or some kind of tablet somewhere in the game that would help you work out what these symbols mean? If anything, it would be a very good reward for players like me who are dedicated enough to seek out the answers within the game.  - Minigames: I don't wan't to spoil any secret minigames so I will refer to them in code.  (A) Dash: The second tier challenge is sheer torture. I wasn't having fun, and it is quite possibly the most horrible thing about the game. I can't imagine any reward in the game (or outside it) being worth completion of that particular minigame.  (B) Ball: Screw this minigame. Holy ****. Your opponent is way too hard from the get-go (he likes to trip you, the little ****), and if that wasn't enough, your character controls the ball like a palsy patient. Yeah, I didn't really feel an overwhelming need to throw myself with gusto into this one, which is kind of an insult considering how wonderfully inviting the rest of the game is.  (C) Fight: Nothing wrong with this one, just a good ol' endurance mode, and you can practice your skills here. I got the reward, and it had the same problem as the other minigames, which is that the juice doesn't justify the squeeze.  What New Players May Experience:  - Steep Difficulty Curve: New players may find the game akin to running their head against a brick wall repeatedly in the hopes that it will break and on the other side will be success. The game kind of dunks you into an ice-cold bath of mistakes, failures, and forcing you to use your head to solve puzzles and find treasure that many gamers might feel unappealing or downright impossible; coming from mainstream games that actually offer you tips and hints if you are stuck, or downright telling you where to go (as is the case with most modern First-Person Shooters).  - Negative Space Syndrome: Okay, this is my amateurish attempt at pop psychology. This game has a lot of quiet moments and a distinct lack of text when it comes to explaining things to the player, so the player might feel a certain distance between themselves and the game that is hard to overcome, especially pertaining to the storyline and the interactions with Non-Player Characters.

Yet very few pixel art games end up looking as impressively gorgeous as Hyper Light Drifter. I can't imagine how many hours must've been spent building and animating its sprawling world, but it has definitely been time well spent.  HLD is an open world action adventure with heavy focus on combat and exploration. You got your hub city where you buy upgrades with the currency gathered from the game's four separate wilderness areas, most of which are available for you to roam at any time. There really aren't any puzzles besides finding weaknesses in enemies attack patterns and figuring your way through the crumbled ruins of a once-great civilization.  Everything in this post-apocalytic fantasy world is dying, including you. The mystical intro sequence seems to depict some kind of great evil being stirred awake as a result of catastrophic event that annihilates most of the populus. While chaos and primitive anarchy embrace the remaining survivors outside the city, you as a lone drifter find yourself in the last bastion of civility, tasked with bringing the derelict machinery back into motion.  Much is left for interpretation. The story is told entirely visually, and there's no text or voice. And as mentioned before, those visuals have a heck of story to tell. The atmosphere in the game is ominous, mysterious, even dreamlike -- Elevated even higher by Disasterpeace's excellent soundtrack. There are small details and secrets everywhere that make the journey a constantly fascinating one.  The control scheme is comfortingly simple, allowing the combat complexities to arise from the enemy numbers. Very often you're fighting five or more enemies at once, bobbing and weaving around the battlefield with your signature dash ability and delivering lethal sword strikes at close range. Nimble fingers and a tactical approach are certainly required, especially when encountering bosses who can regularly end you with just a couple of blows if given the chance.  Hyper Light Drifter has a fully realized, imaginative vision, an impeccable sense of style and hours of satisfying gameplay. Last year I really enjoyed Axiom Verge's modernized take on retro game design, but I think I like this one even more.
Buy it, then you can thank me for kickstarting it.
