TL;DR: fun and challenging game that doesn't over stay it's welcome, the OST is perfect and no sound doesn't fit the aesthetic of the location or situation. Each fight feels earned espcially boss fights. Overall very satisfying  I got Hyper Light Drifter on a whim, it looked like a cute little game and I was looking for something that had some metroidvania elements and it looked fun. It started with an amazing cinmatic that had me going from ??? to !!! and then finally ?!?!?!   Story-wise, I'm not saying anything. HLD is one of those game that's best experianced the less you know about it. It never overstayed it's welcome and was very enthralling, having my attention the whole time I was playing.  There is no dialouge in the game, at all, the only text there is anywhere is in the menu and parts of the tutorial (like 'press Y to interact' or 'LB to heal') other than that everything is purely visual, and left up to Player Interpretation which is neat! NPCs will tell you (The Drifter) stories but it'll be in pictures where you have to peice together what happened and why. There's shopkeepers but even there is no dialouge or text for what you can buy, pictures with examples of what it is. The fanbase and the wiki have given them names such as 'Dash Master' for the shopkeeper who sells Dash Upgrades.  The combat is perfect and nothing feels out of place, while I'd love a parry ability I have a feeling that Drifter will get by just fine without it. You have only three swings of your sword at once before you will have to either use your gun or back away, most enemies only have 3 hits. It's fairly easy to balance using your gun, optional bomb, and your sword while dashing around the room. With various upgrades combat gets easier but it can also build overconfidence. Loads of times I'd walk away from the battle with only 1 out of my 3 medkits and still only have 1 hp left because 'oh I'll be fine, I have all the upgrades for my sword and dashing!' and would promptly get stomped.   The music is perfect, when things are calm it fits the mood and helps create a peaceful atmosphere. There's parts of the game where the sound is discorient and 'glitchy' to set you off and god does it do that well. The battle music is LOUD and intense especially when you're fighting a boss, I found it at times it was hard for me to keep my cool with both the music making me excited and the boss fight freaking me out with their respective attacks.   There's tons of secrets one can go find, lots of swords, cloaks, sprites (little robo dude who follows you around) as well as gearbits (currency) to help make getting the upgrades easier. Prepair for keyhunting if you're a completionist, there's at least one door that requires all of them. There's guns that you can only get through this exploration and it's really cool  Chain dashing was possibly the best thing in the game 10/10 would again smash my face against every wall, tree, bush, and rock in the game. Heart Machine really pulled through with making you actually fall down, make a crashing noise when you hit the surface, and then get up after a second. There's two challenges at Dash Master's for chain dashing, one for 100 dashes and one for 800 dashes. Do them, you won't regret it.  If you decide 'well I don't think that's challenging enough' there's an achivement for never dying ever in the game, as well as NG+ that strips you of 3 of your hit points. Normally you have 5, in NG+ you have 2. Welcome to hell

You are a drifter in a world run amock by unexplained powers, everywhere you look there is death and decay in abundance. Wandering (drifting, if you will) through these vast wastelands and gazing upon scenes of past conflict really brought me to complete awestruck silence.  As for combat, the game very much delivers. Hyper Light Drifter provides a fun, fast paced bullet hell enviroment to the player. Given you only have five health, and most enemies deal 2-3 damage on average, it really serves to amp up the pressure. Every attack seems like a death sentence hurtling towards you at breakneck speed, but given the drifter's dash ability I felt like a f****** ninja all the way through, dodging lethal attacks in an instant and dashing behind a foe to slice him in half.   Unlike many games now, HLD was very challenging for me. It is a very non-linear experience, and I always enjoy a challenge. The map was extremely vague whilst searching for certain items to complete the storyline, and I adore this idea. I had to find each one for myself, slashing at walls and bushes to see if any pathway was hiding in the undergrowth, or backtrack many times and find a place I had never explored before. If you are a person who enjoys exploration, I suggest picking this game up immediately.  As for the non-linear story, I also enjoyed it. It allowed me to go off on my own and find things out for myself, not just have the game's helping hand give everything to me without even trying. Another important note is that the game contains no dialogue, but rather characters tell the story through pictures. Each cutscene is also beautifully animated, and I like to think the games story exists for your own interpretation. (Side Note: If you like cryptic codes, there is also plenty of secrets in the game for you to find as well)  All in all, Hyper Light Drifter is my favorite game at the moment. It is stunning visually, and the gameplay has enough variation and enemy variety that it never seems repetitive. I would give this game a solid 10/10 because it is a fabulous indie title, very different and refreshing to see so early in the year. Thanks for reading BTW, this is the first review I've done for a game.

Hyper Light Drifter is elegant.   In this game, you control The Drifter, (Known to some as The Magician). The Drifter is young and is afflicted by a terrible disease that ravages their heart, causing them great pain and making them cough up copius amounts of blood. Despite this, The Drifter journeys across the world seeking a cure.   What makes Hyper Light Drifter such a memorable and special experience more than anything is that everything fits nicely into place. Exploring, Battling enemies, and finding items is what Hyper Light Drifter is all about, and each one serves the other in some way.  The gameplay consists of zipping around the world with your Hyper Dash ability. Drifter can dash a set distance at the push of a button. This mechanic makes HLD feel so incredibly slick. It's also a very versatile ability to have, as it helps you to traverse the environment, move insanely fast, and dodge attacks during battle.   Using your Hard Light sword, your EMP Grenades, and your Cell Battery Firearms, you'll Slash, Rend, Cleave, Stab, Slam, Blast, Shoot, Snipe, and Frag your way through hordes of enemies, all the while dancing through danger with your Hyper Dash. The combat is difficult to master, but very easy to understand. It's visceral and fast paced, without being impossible to deal with.  As you progress through the game and explore the vast, ruinous world. you will find treasures like weapons, clothing, currency, and Power Cells. But that's not all you will encounter. Around every corner could be gorgeous landscapes, or horrid and savage scenarios. The world is full of death, dismemberment, and fallen Gods.  The story of HLD is largely open to interpretation, and is a discovery in and of itself. You will happen upon gruesome scenes of violence and death, breathtakingly beautiful vistas, and mysterious, obtuse imagery that begs you to put more thought into what you're looking at. This to me is the real treasure of Hyper Light Drifter. Finding out what happened to this world, and learning your place within it is more fulfilling than any fancy gun the game could ever give me. There is so much to think about regarding the game's lore, and there is even a language in the game that you need to actually translate yourself to understand. If you thought your discovery ended inside the game, it does not. It seeps out of the screen into your real life and implores you to ask more questions.  <TLDR: I highly recommend Hyper Light Drifter. If you love action, it has all the pulse pounding battles you could ever want. If you love exploration and adventure, there are treasures. and secrets abound. If you want to know more about the ancient history of a broken alien world, you have lots to investigate. And if you simply love beautiful, hand animated, colorful pixel art, this is one of the greatest showcases of Pixel art on the market.>  Happy Drifting!

I bought this game on an impulse. I looked at it, and I thought it looked like an easy, fun way to spend a few hours on a Zelda-like adventure. I was compleatly correct in buying it, but oh so wrong about why. This game is essentially a piece of art. It is elegant, smooth, and simplistic, while also being tough, gritty, and downright difficult. It is truly wonderful.  Pros:  - Great concept, the dashing mechanic makes your character feel lightweight, making it engaging to dodge attacks.  - Gorgeous pixel art, seriously I dont think I've seen a more beautiful game than this in a while. The colors of the different sections of the game have a serious effect on you.   For instance, the light greens and the blue of the water in the eastern area make the setting feel free and open, while the dark blues and purples of the west make the area feel repressed and dark.    - Wonderful soundtrack, the creative electronic sounds add a certain weight to the music that I haven't heard from anything else.  - Tells you virtually nothing except how to execute basic actions. Nothing about where you're going, why you're going, or how you're going. This allows you to create you're own reasons for doing what you do, and to really think about what is really going on. This is an idea that is becoming popular in today's gaming, like Undertale or any of the Telltale games, but this game presents the idea in a different way. Instead of making you  choose  what you're doing, it makes you  wonder why  you're doing it.   Cons: - While the lack of direction in the game is extreamly well done in most places, there's a few things I wish were more clarified. For instance,   the goal in the first three areas of the game is to acquire four of these little white diamond things to progress to the boss fight. This is not made clear to the player, and it took me a good amount of time to figure out what was happening and what I was supposed to do. Also, the first three areas can be completed in any order you like, but this was somewhat confusing and it left me with a feeling of doubt as to what I was doing was the correct thing to do.   While I found these to be problem areas of the game, I'm sure some people would really appreciate these features, so remember this is only my opinion.  - Some of the boss fights, to me, felt much easier than others. I feel like this would be ok, if they approached the game without   letting you complete the first three areas in any order,   but if they implemented that mechanic then they should have balanced the fights more. For example,    I completed the first three areas in this order: North, East, then West. Out of those three bosses, the North was the most challenging for me, the West the second, then the East by far being the easiest. The North and West bosses I spent at least an hour to two hours trying to complete, and when I finally beat them I had already memorized all of their attack patterns. However, I beat the Eastern boss in one try, and it barely attacked once before I killed it. It was so easy that I thought for a good thirty seconds that the   real   boss was going to pop out and kill me. But that was the actual boss. The North and West bosses are probably equal in difficulty, and the North boss was probably harder for me because I fought him first, while with the West I already had experience with the game, but the East boss was just stupid easy.    Conclusion: While the cons section may appear thick with critisism, most of that writing is explanations for why I disliked a tiny detail. In all, those details do very little to affect the whole game, which is truly a masterpeice. I strongly reccomend purchasing this game, and I hope to see more from this developer in the future.  Verdict: 9.5/10

I nominate this game for a Steam Award, in my suggested category 'Winning This Game Feels Like Real Victory'.  I have some pretty strong feelings about this game, so it seems only natural that this be the one I review and explain my 'write-in' category nomination for. This game provides real, intense action like I've never seen in a game before, like you would never believe that pixel art can.  The art and music are amazing, before we forget to mention those, and were the things that first drew me in while the game was in development. Character design is diverse but functional; backgrounds, lighting, and color, are all striking and just pleasant to look at with their blend of darks and neons, natural tones and eerie glows; and all of it is tied together beautifully with that gorgeous soundtrack that gives the impression that you really have stepped into a lost, alien world. But artistic appeal wasn't a category in the Steam Awards and, as incredible as it is in 'Hyper Light Drifter', that wasn't even my favorite part of the game.  My favorite part was the action. Dashing, slashing, and shooting your way through traps, obstacles, and a whole lot of bad things lurking in the dark, you have all the tools you need to dance your way through them without taking a scratch right at the outset. You will not. As deadly as you are, you are very mortal and you must learn the flow of combat, when to press your advantage and when to withdraw, in order to survive each encounter.  Death, of course, is inevitable. This game does not hold your hand as you explore its ruins. You must learn through experience and experience is earned through some degree of repetition. Death is not cruel, however, and any sticking points can be backed out of to return to later, sometimes skipped over as optional challenges if necessary, and are engaging enough you probably won't want to anyway. The result is potent challenges which remain fresh and intense as you hone your skills until you surpass them. As an added bonus, once you have, the victory flourish your character performs after such segments is immensely satisfying.  Which brings me to the subject of victory, the sense of victory that 'Hyper Light Drifter' provides above and beyond all the other games I've ever played. There is more than a mere destination in Hyper Light Drifter. There is comparitively very little in the way of static upgrades in power to accumulate along your journey. There is a challenge, posed to you throughout the experience of playing, and there is the skill and drive you have to overcome it. Odds which once seemed impossible come into perspective upon playing through them again and, looking back, you can see how much you've grown. No artificial boost or cheap trick did it for you. Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent action game. It plays a lot like the old-school Legend of Zelda games. The combat is challenging but fair. The story is very minimalist (more so than in Dark Sousl), but I think it works in this game. The art style and music are both incredible as well.   Before the patch that changed the game from 30 FPS to 60 FPS, I wasn't a huge fan of this game. But, the 60 FPS makes this game a lot of fun -- kudos to the dev for taking the time to fix the framerate.   There a lot of collectibles/secrets in this game. It depends on the game, but usually I am not a fan of collectibles. I'm not knocking the game for having collectibles, but I did find it kind of annoying that a lot of the secrets felt hit or miss...the few that I found involved having to hug the edge of the map.   Overall, Hyper Light Drifter is a great and very fun action game.
